metadata.sermon_start_end: WE’VE BEEN in Exodus for a while; many of you will remember the reading for last Sunday, which tells of the golden calf which the people of Israel made in the wilderness while Moses was up on Mount Sinai receiving the Commandments from the Lord. [...] He is the One who was shamed in front of the whole world, for us, the ungodly. It is for ourselves, this very night, that the Lord’s table of welcome is now spread.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon stays close to the narrative of Exodus 32-33. It identifies a specific theological point—the mediation of Moses as a shield—but struggles to articulate what is found *nowhere else* in the Bible, eventually merging the text into a general Pauline theology of atonement.
quotes: The morning after the smashing of the golden calf, Moses said to the people... 'perhaps I can make atonement for your sin.'
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Isolate the unique character of Moses' intercession in this specific crisis compared to other intercessors like Abraham or Jeremiah to avoid generalities.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher shows awareness of the literary structure and irony. However, there is no evidence of the required 'Hebrew and Greek' or deep historical-critical engagement demanded by Dekker. The exegesis remains at the level of narrative observation.
quotes: In the fashion of biblical storytelling, the irony in this is only lightly touched upon.
Whether Moses is a literary creation or not I will leave others to debate
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Incorporate the specific linguistic nuances of the 'stiff-necked' metaphor or the technical meaning of 'atonement' in the Pentateuchal context.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is very concrete, specifically addressing the 2008 financial crisis and the 'zeitgeist' of rage against CEOs. It avoids general moralism by grounding the human condition in a specific historical moment.
quotes: the great god for quite a while has been The Market.
the names and faces of these grossly overpaid executives are posted for all to see.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move beyond the collective 'market' to the personal spiritual state of the hearer in the pew to prevent the application from becoming a social commentary.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon successfully weaves the Wall Street crisis into the narrative of the Golden Calf. However, the transition to the New Testament at the end feels like a separate section rather than a continued movement of the text.
quotes: Now Wall Street has been shaken... I am told that from every pulpit in the States, the refrain has come...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Ensure the contemporary application (the 'Market') is 'expounded' by the text itself rather than used as a parallel illustration.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Misery (idolatry/greed) and Redemption (Moses/Christ as shield) are present. Gratitude is the weakest element, appearing only briefly at the end regarding the Lord's Table.
quotes: These people have sinned a great sin
His glory is shown in his mercy.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'gratitude' section. How does the 'shielded' life look in practice after the crisis?

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon flirts with the 'two ways' by mentioning the 'annihilating holiness' and 'righteous wrath,' but ultimately softens the blow. The possibility of being truly 'lost' is mitigated by the focus on the shield.
quotes: his own unmediated presence would consume them in the flame of his righteous wrath.
he will nevertheless take them up to the Promised Land
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the reality of those who *remain* with the bull-god. The seriousness of the choice must be a live option for the hearer.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is the clear telos. The sermon moves from the type (Moses) to the antitype (Christ) effectively. It upholds the doctrine of grace as salvation outside of oneself.
quotes: He is the One who was shamed in front of the whole world, for us, the ungodly.
a greater One than Moses is here.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Avoid making Christ a 'solution' to a narrative problem; ensure He is presented as the Lord who demands a response.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1550 words, the sermon likely clocks in at 15-16 minutes. According to Dekker, this lacks the 'breadth' required for true depth.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical and dogmatic background to reach the 20-minute threshold.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker’s standard primarily in its duration and the depth of its original-language exegesis. It succeeds in providing a concrete, contemporary application regarding the financial crisis and maintains a clear Christological focus. However, it lacks the 'sharpness' of the two ways, leaning heavily on the shield of grace without sufficiently emphasizing the peril of the 'stiff-necked' choice.
strengths: Concrete application to the 2008 financial crisis avoids 'general truths'.
Strong Christological telos that connects the Old Testament type to the Gospel.
Effective use of irony to expose modern idolatry.
weaknesses: Duration is insufficient (approx. 15 min) for the 'breadth' Dekker requires.
Lack of explicit engagement with Hebrew/Greek or scholarly exegesis.
The 'two ways' are present but lack the necessary urgency and threat of being lost.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a 'satisfactory' attempt at a sermon but lacks the scholarly rigor and temporal breadth Dekker demands. It is more of a theological meditation than a full 'exposition and application' of the Word.
